title-group.article-title: Rethinking Cities in Contentious Times: The Mobilisation of Urban Dissent in the ‘Arab Spring’

author-notes.corresp: Marco Allegra is in CIES, University of Lisbon, Edificio ISCTE, Avenida das Forças Armadas, Lisbon, 1649-026, Portugal. Email: marco.allegra@ymail.com.
Irene Bono is in the Department of Culture, Politics and Society, University of Torino, Lungo Dora Siena 100, Turin, 10123, Italy. Email: irenebono@gmail.com.
Jonathan Rokem and Haim Yacobi are in the Department of Politics and Government, Ben-Gurion University of the Negev, Israel. Email: jonathanrock1@gmail.com and yacobih@bgu.ac.il.

Anna Casaglia and Roberta Marzorati are in the Department of Sociolgy and Social Research, Università di Milano Bicocca, via Bicocca degli Arcimboldi 8, Milano, 20126, Italy. Email: anna.casaglia@unimib.it and roberta.marzorati@gmail.com.

abstract.p: Throughout history, cities have been the theatre of social and spatial struggles. The issue of urban protests, however, has not yet been investigated in detail in the light of the growing concern of the need to rethink urban studies, from theoretical and epistemic assumptions, to methodological issues. It is argued that the mobilisation of urban dissent in the so-called Arab Spring offers a good opportunity to develop a critical approach based on the observation of the nexus between an event (a punctual expression of dissent) and a site (the urban environment in which the former takes place). The goal is to avoid theoretical rigidities inherent to the assumptions about the intrinsic qualities of cities or social movements. The paper also aims at connecting different academic and disciplinary traditions across linguistic divides—and especially the Anglophone urban studies with the Francophone stream of city-focused political science and political sociology.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: As we write this Commentary, almost two years passed since the so-called Arab Spring broke out. In December 2010, a seemingly minor event—the self-immolation of Mohamed Bouazizi, a Tunisian street vendor protesting against the confiscation of his merchandise by the police in the town of Sidi Bouzid—catalysed widespread discontent into huge mass protests. The uprising eventually resulted in the ousting of president Ben Ali in January 2011. After Tunisia, many other countries of the Middle East and North Africa were invested by different expressions of dissent, often adopting similar repertories of action for contesting local leaders. Regime changes took place in Egypt and Libya, and massive protest shook Algeria, Yemen, Bahrein, and even seemingly stable countries such as Jordan, Morocco, and Saudi Arabia, while in Syria protests ultimately gave way to an armed insurrection against the regime of Bashar al Assad. After its inception in Tunisia, the ‘poster child of the Arab Spring’ rapidly became the picture of the Egyptian crowd occupying Tahrir Square in Cairo, a powerful image of protest replicated in other cities in the Middle East and North Africa (MENA)—such as the Pearl roundabout in Manama, Bahrain—and beyond, inspiring the “Occupy movement” globally encapsulating mass protests in a large number of major cities world-wide.

Throughout history, cities have been the theatre of social and spatial struggles—from national revolutions to local riots—indeed, issues of social justice and protest have represented an object of enquiry in urban studies (Simmel, 1903/1950; Touraine, 1969; Harvey, 1973; Lefebvre, 1974; Castells, 1983; Lowe, 1986; Young, 1990; Merrifield and Swyngedouw, 1996; Mitchell, 2003; Nicholls and Beaumont, 2004a). The issue of urban protest, however, has not yet been investigated in detail in the light of the growing concern of the need to rethink urban studies, from theoretical and epistemic assumptions, to methodological and ethical issues (Amin and Thrift, 2002; Simone, 2004a; Robinson, 2006, 2011; Ward, 2010; MacLeod and Jones, 2011), which has risen in parallel with a renewed interest in the urban dimension of social phenomena.

The mobilisation of urban dissent in the Arab Spring offers us a good opportunity to develop a critical approach with respect to two crucial themes: the very definition of the city as an object of study and the relation between the latter and protests. This Commentary is therefore meant to collect and critically discuss a number of suggestions emerging from the field of urban studies, and further afield. Its aim is to delineate a possible set of epistemic and methodological premises required to build a meaningful research agenda on the urban socio-spatial dimension of the current political turmoil in the MENA region.

We provide a few words on the background of this Commentary in order to clarify its scope and purposes. This paper develops the ideas we first elaborated for the workshop proposal “Rethinking cities and social movements in Middle East and North Africa”, submitted to the 2011 Urban Studies Foundation and Urban Studies Journal Seminar Series Competition. This event was conceived as a workshop to be attended by social scientists of various disciplinary, linguistic and national backgrounds, all of them working on urban themes or contexts—although not necessarily from an urban studies perspective. Its main purpose was to foster a discussion on the role of cities in the on-going upheaval in MENA and its implication in terms of future research. In writing this Commentary, we tried to develop an ideal platform, rather than an empirical paper, for such a diverse audience of contributors.

Within this perspective, we suggest that the cities that are the theatre of protests should not be taken for granted as objects defined by and understood through a set of given theoretical propositions and models. On the one side, we should avoid theoretical rigidities inherent to the assumptions about the intrinsic qualities of a model ‘MENA’/‘Arab’/‘Islamic’ city—or to any other strict and exclusive definition of urbanity. On the other side, we should question the heuristic value of urban protests as an indicator of structural patterns developing in cities that are the stage of these phenomena. In other words, models about ‘what the city is’ and ‘what protests are’ do not seem useful enough to us for capturing cities in contentious times.

We maintain that it is instead the observation of the nexus between an event (a punctual expression of dissent, which can take the form of a strike or a protest) and a site (the urban environment in which the former takes place) that offers us the most interesting angle to comprehend both. In other words, cities are privileged sites for understanding the social and historical nature of dissent expressed by struggles and protests; at the same time, protest can serve as a key point of access to apprehend the urban dimension of politics. Last but not least, our paper also aims at connecting different academic traditions and bodies of literature across linguistic divides—the Anglophone urban studies with the Francophone stream of city-focused political science and political sociology—by considering a unit of analysis and a research theme that are traditionally important for both.

sec.title: 2. The Stage: Cities in the MENA Region
sec.p:
As happens with respect to many other components of our personal and social experience, we know perfectly well what a city is until the moment we try to spell out its precise definition. For urban researchers, this is further complicated by the growing realisation that the urban world is not only physically but also qualitatively expanding
The city is everywhere and everything … The traditional divide between the city and the countryside has been perforated (Amin and Thrift, 2002, p. 2).

How can we consequently define ‘cityness’? And how can we elaborate meaningful theoretical categories to describe the urban? The on-going debate in urban studies offers us a useful starting-point to address this crucial issue in the light of the current turmoil in the MENA region, as it individuates two main lacunae in the production of urban theory.

A first strand of criticism relates to the way theory and categories are produced and used. Theoretically speaking, urban studies would suffer from what Amin and Graham (1997) define as a ‘problem of synecdoche’—namely, the derivation of general theories or taxonomies from the observation of few empirical examples (see also Beauregard, 2003; McFarlane, 2010). A reverse but equivalent bias is addressed in more general terms by Jessop et al. (2008) in their critique of mutually exclusive, one-dimensional approaches to socio-spatial analysis. While aiming at the universalisation of epistemic categories and rigorous conceptualisation, these practices, the critique goes, are ultimately self-defeating. To the extent that a restricted number of cities or concepts assume the role of paradigmatic yardsticks, against which all socio-spatial phenomena should be measured, the resulting theoretical achievement is likely to be extremely parochial and geographically one-sided, lacking reflexivity and dependent on short-lived cycles of intellectual fashion.

A second and related element of criticism points to the political, institutional and cultural biases that are often inherent in this approach. Theory-building often tends to be driven by strategies of academic positioning and hegemony (Beauregard, 2003; Robinson, 2003; McFarlane, 2006). More generally, it reproduces and creates hierarchies and asymmetries among regions in the world
Paradigmatic claims also encourage an exclusive urban theory—a ‘discursive hierarchy’ … that eliminates a multitude of cities from theoretical gaze … Only deviations from the paradigmatic norm are recognized as signiﬁcant. More speciﬁcally, exclusivity marginalizes two types of cities: ordinary cities and cities in developing countries (Beauregard, 2003, p. 190).

Not surprisingly, variations on Beauregard’s argument are constantly voiced by those advocating a post-colonial sensitivity in urban studies, who lament the relegation of the cities of the global South to the role of deviant, incomplete, dystopian urban systems, as well as the scarce consideration of academic and linguistic traditions other than the Western/Anglophone (Simone, 2004a; Mbembe and Nuttall, 2004; Robinson, 2006, 2011; Roy, 2009, 2011; MacLeod and Jones, 2011).

Much of the urban studies literature on cities of the MENA region—traditionally neglected by the Anglophone mainstream urban studies—suffers from the two flaws just described. As Janet Abu-Lughod (1987; see also Hourani and Stern, 1970, for an earlier critique) showed, the classic literature on the so-called Islamic city offers us a blatant example of how a general theory on the city of the region was built through the observation of few cases of (mostly) North African cities and the orientalist (Said, 1977), uncritical assumption of the role of ‘Islam’ as an explanatory factor for urban development and form. Despite this early criticism, scholarship on MENA cities seems still dominated by a form of ‘urban orientalism’ perpetuating an essentialist, Weberian-type discussion on the ‘Islamic’, ‘oriental’, traditional nature of MENA cities (see for example, Serageldin and El-Sadek, 1982; Hakim, 1986; Akbar, 1988; AlSayyad, 1991; Al-Hathloul, 1996; Stewart, 2001). With few, significant exceptions (Mitchell, 1988; Hamadeh, 1992; Çelik, 1997; Fuccaro, 2001; Elsheshtawy, 2004, 2008; AlSayyad et al., 2005; Singerman and Ammar, 2006; Singerman, 2009; Mayaram, 2009; see also the special issue of Cities edited by Relli Shechter and Haim Yacobi in 2006), the cities of the region are usually considered as only marginally touched by globalisation and as passive objects of these trends.

We suggest that these flaws should be corrected in order to capture the urban dimension of the ‘Arab Spring’. The debate developing within urban studies suggests a number of ways to do so, by recognising: the fundamental socio-spatial features of the city as a locus of dense social interactions, of juxtaposition of heterogeneity (Amin and Thrift, 1995, 2002; Amin and Graham, 1997; Pile, 1999; Massey, 1999); the contingent nature of scalar contexts (Brenner, 2001) and, more generally, the need for a contextual and polymorphic assessment of sociospatial phenomena (Jessop et al., 2008); the embeddedness of the city in a system of flows and networks that go beyond its physical definition (Amin, 2004; Massey, 2004, 2007; Ward, 2010); the blurring boundaries between agency and structure (Amin and Thrift, 2002; Simone, 2004b); the fundamental relational and cultural dimension of city life (Pieterse, 2005; Till, 2012); and the acknowledgement of the notion of ‘plural causality’ (Pickvance, 1986; Robinson, 2011). Methodologically speaking, this conceptualisation of the city emphasises the value of case study analysis and urban ethnographies as fundamental research tools (Fregonese, 2009; Till, 2012; see Castells, 1983, for an early example).

Another valuable contribution can come from the Francophone academic tradition of urban research. Following a pattern developed during the 1980s—through both in-depth case studies of single cities (Signoles and Belhedi, 1980; Belfiqh and Fadloullah, 1986; Sgroi-Dufresne, 1986) and researches on contentious politics adopting the city as the main scale of analysis (see for example, Brown, 1989)—a number of later contributions (Denoeux, 1993; Rachik, 1995; Bennani-Chraïbi and Filleuille, 2003; Souami and Verdeil, 2006; Verdeil, 2010) opened the way for a new research agenda rooted in political science and political sociology, focusing more specifically on issues of governance and the exercise of power at the urban level (see for example, Berry-Chikhaoui and Deboulet, 2000; Arnaud, 2005; Elyachar, 2005; Drieskens et al., 2007; Iraki et al., 2009; Zaki, 2010; Peraldi and Tozy, 2011; Barthel and Zaki, 2011).

As a whole, these contributions help us to acknowledge a more complex notion of urbanity. More than emphasising a set of given qualities associated with the urban environment, they suggest ways to explore it in order to escape theoretical and disciplinary reductionisms. This starting-point enables us to delineate the contours of the city as a meaningful site in which to analyse dissent.

sec.title: 3. The Event: Protests of the ‘Arab Spring’
sec.p: The observation of different expressions of dissent that came to public attention in the MENA region through the frame of the ‘Arab Spring’ challenges several of the central assumptions of the academic reflection on contentious politics.

In the first place, from an urban social movement perspective, the city is mainly seen as the environment that creates the structural conditions for dissent to emerge and be expressed. There is in fact a long and established tradition of enquiry which sees the city as a place of alienation marked by poverty, segregation, lack of security, violence, repression and the loss of communitarian ties, with these structural features automatically producing the potential for social struggle (Simmel 1903/1950; Touraine 1969; Lefebvre 1974; Castells 1983; Young 1990; Negri 2008). More recently, Routledge argued that we should recognise the
contemporary strategic importance [of the urban scale] at a time when (neo-liberal) capitalism has been pursued particularly vehemently in cities (Routledge, 2010, p. 1172).

Urban protest is in many ways the expression of dissent par excellence: the iconic value of Tahrir Square, and other similar images from Bourguiba Avenue in Tunis, rests on the widely acknowledged metonymic role of urban protest in figuring out social and political change, initiating from episodes such as the storming of the Bastille in 1789. However, we maintain that research on the Arab Spring should refrain from framing the turmoil as an ‘exclusive urban phenomenon’ by tracing its roots in urban issues and politics (see for example, Verdeil, 2011, on the failing urban economy of the MENA region). The urban dimension seems to be a component of the expressions of dissent deployed in the MENA region—albeit admittedly an important one, and especially for what concerns its public visibility to a local and global audience.

In the second place, the study of social movements and contentious politics tends to focus on specific actors and forms of dissent; it focuses in other words on the different ways in which dissent is expressed, rather than on dissent itself—or at least it conflates the two phenomena (i.e. Della Porta and Diani, 2006; on MENA countries: Le Saout and Rollinde, 1999; Bennani-Chraïbi and Fileuille, 2003; Cronin, 2008; Beinin and Vairel, 2011). Some scholars focus on the different forms that collective action can take and generally tend to construct images of social movements as homogeneous actors with a high level of strategic ability. The effort to give a specific spatial and urban turn to this theoretical body through the notion of ‘urban (social) movements’ (Nicholls and Beaumont, 2004a, 2004b; Routledge, 2010) is not sufficient to our argument; if the Arab Spring is not an exclusively urban phenomenon, in turn, then restricting the field of investigation to “movements that are organisationally grounded in cities and whose strategies focus on altering the urban” (Nicholls and Beaumont, 2004a, p. 111) is not sufficient to capture the width and complexity of the turmoil.

In the third place, academic research on urban social movements in the MENA region is often caught, as Asef Bayat (2009) notes, between the surrender to the exceptionalism of the MENA region and the same theoretical parochialism inherent to the notion of Amin and Graham’s ‘problem of synecdoche’ (Amin and Graham, 1997). In recent decades, this tendency has mainly translated in MENA countries into an overproduction about ‘civil society’ and ‘Islamist movements’ as the main protagonists of contentious politics. More recently, the copious production of conferences, special issues of journals and edited books that followed the inception of the Arab Spring generally confirms this tendency—adding to that, the mention of ‘youth’ as main agents in the era of the so called twitter revolutions (for example, Murphy, 2012)—even though these broad categories do not seem completely convincing for capturing the dynamic of dissent currently expressed in the MENA region. As Bayat convincingly argues, the heuristic value of the prevailing social movement theory that draws on Western experience for accounting “the complexities of socioreligious movements” in contemporary Muslim societies should be questioned
To what extent can they help us understand the process of solidarity building or the collectivities of disjointed yet parallel practices of noncollective actors in the non-western politically closed and technologically limited settings? (Bayat, 2009, p. 4).

We should stress that this does not amount to critique of the social movement theory per se—which would remain anyway outside the purpose of this brief paper—but is rather a choice of focusing on something different with respect to the object of enquiry usually chosen by this literature. Starting from the conceptualisation of cities as sites, capturing protests as ‘events’—as Bayart (2008) suggests conceiving social phenomena, pointing to the Deleuzian comprehension of this notion—implies focusing more widely on the specific forms that dissent can assume in a specific political situation precisely located in place and time; more than on protest itself, on how dissent shapes the phenomenon under examination and on what that reveals to us about it. Dissent does not merely correspond to protest; its comprehension requires taking into account its local and contingent characteristics, as well as acknowledging its longue durée and the socio-historical environment in which its manifestations take place.

This effort of contextualisation is to be generalised to dissent itself as a phenomenon that might be expressed in several different forms. ‘Bringing dissent back in’ implies, in other words, not just considering it within the categories of social movements and collective actors, but broadening instead the angle of analysis to include different actions of ‘the citizens’ socially comprehended as ‘dissent’, beyond its manifestation through the forms traditionally considered by the frame of contentious politics. Once again, the work of Asef Bayat (1997, 2009) and in particular his notion of ‘non-movements’ (pointing to the “collective actions of noncollective actors” as a key social dynamic in the MENA region; Bayat, 2009, p. 4) represents an important contribution in taking into account the embeddedness of the different expressions of dissent in daily social life—and ultimately blurring the borders between the former and other social actions. Dissenting is rarely the main—and never the only—activity of the individuals and ‘the protester’ is far from being their only role in society. Every protester has at the same time some other roles and he/she is inserted in a web of political, social and economic relations, which certainly ease his/her mobilisation, but also a variety of different social actions. Crucially, dissent does not necessarily correspond to a conflict about a certain political order, but may rather express a demand of integration in such order, and may even be a guarantee of its regeneration. The explosion of dissent in small and peripheral cities of the MENA region, for example, might be read as a way of questioning unequal regional repartition of resources, rather than as an indicator of urban segregation.

Taking into account the protest as an ‘event’ among others allows looking at such expressions of dissent in continuity with the wider political situation. By adopting such perspective, starting assumptions between the structural (vs contextual and historical) characteristics of the site (i.e. the city) and the emergence of the event (i.e. the protest) are to be relaxed. Many scholars have paid attention to the structural elements justifying the expression of dissent and have often assumed a positive relation between certain configurations of social structure and the emergence of specific types of contentious collective behaviour—in this case, linking traits of urban life to the emergence of specific forms of resistance. Following Thompson’s reflection on ‘moral economy’—originally proposed to capture the uprising of the English working class in the 18th century (Thompson, 1963, 1971), commonly adopted by some political sociologists for exploring the production and diffusion of moral models (see for example, Fassin and Eideliman, 2012) and recently proposed in relation to the Tunisian unrest (Hibou, 2006/2011)—such a perspective implies overcoming the causal chain often taken for granted between some characteristics of the city (such as inequality or marginalisation) and a sentiment of social injustice, dissent, social conflict and political change, and questioning the potential of cities to create plural social movements. Protests can come with disadvantaged economic conditions, but the latter can never be considered a sufficient explanatory factor. The contextuality and contingency of the turmoil are to be considered two of its fundamental properties, which might explain its unexpectedness.

We therefore welcome the growing interest by geographers and urban studies scholars in the issue of social movements and social change with respect to specific ‘local contents’ of social and political struggles (Nicholls, 2007) and the concept of social justice as a ‘localised’ or ‘contingent’ value, rooted in the daily life of people, or the contextualisation of mobilisations proposed by some political sociologists (Cefaï, 2007). In line with our observations about ‘cityness’, we feel that framing the city as a pool of institutional, informational, relational and material resources available to social movements, as well as to any other actor able to take advantage of them (non-movements, private organisations, criminal gangs, government agencies, etc.) is more productive for our purpose than focusing on the characteristics of the movements themselves—see in this respect the idea of cities as entities of multiple and specific qualities (Amin and Graham, 1997) marked by a high social political and institutional ‘density’ (Amin and Thrift, 1995); or ‘relational incubators’ (Nicholls, 2008).

sec.title: 4. The Site/Event Nexus: Looking at Urban Dissent in the MENA Region
sec.p: The arguments about urban theory, cityness and protests developed in the previous paragraphs frame our approach to the study of urban dissent in the MENA region. We suggest that considering the combination of a ‘site’ and an ‘event’ allows us to look to a set of politically relevant phenomena, which are different from—but at the same time do tell us something about—both of these objects.

In other words, cities should not be considered self-enclosed objects with a detailed set of inherent qualities, but rather as privileged sites for capturing and comprehending the social and historical nature of dissent expressed by struggles. In reverse, we should not consider protests as the most significant phenomena occurring in the city during ‘contentious times’, or the unique characteristics of cities as the main explanatory factors for dissent, but rather as points of access (Ferguson, 1990) for capturing politics and the exercise of power starting from the urban level. This choice, we argue, not only leads us to broaden our object of study when looking at the intersection between cities and protests, but has also methodological and theoretical implications.

Considering the site/event nexus requires a relaxation of the theoretical assumptions, and the adoption of a socio-historical approach that emphasises the importance of contextuality and favours the production of ‘thick descriptions’ of the reality observed—on the model of Bent Flyvbjerg’s ‘Foucauldian case studies’ (Flyvbjerg, 2001, 2006), Bruno Latour’s ‘mapping of controversies’ (Latour, 2005; Venturini, 2010)—with an emphasis on case study analysis (Castells, 1983) and ethnographic tools (Fregonese, 2009; Till, 2012). At the same time, the researcher’s task should not be to look for the ‘cause’ of the Arab Spring, for a general definition or explanation of the phenomenon itself—the same flaw relevant to much of the literature on ‘Islam’ or ‘civil society’. In a comparative-interpretive fashion, we should instead investigate the local diversity and meanings attached to such a broad, regional phenomenon; in other words, how Moroccans or Tunisians or Syrians look to the Arab Spring and what dissent means in the local context. From this point of view, Clifford Geertz’s classical work (1968) on the local declinations of Islam in Morocco and Indonesia represents a point of reference, as well as Asef Bayat’s (1997, 2009) on street politics in Cairo and Tehran, and Jean-François Bayart’s (2010) approach to the study of Republican Islam in Ankara, Teheran and Dakar.

This theoretical move incorporates the epistemic and methodological suggestions advanced by a number of critical urban scholars, but more broadly, it echoes debates already developed about the role of social science as a whole (Flyvbjerg, 2001), as well as in other disciplines such as political science (the ‘area studies controversy’ in the 1990s and the ‘Perestroika movement’ in the 2000s; see Bates, 1996, 1997; Johnson, 1997; Lustick, 1997; Mr Perestroika, 2000; Monroe, 2005), public policy (interpretive public policy; see Yanow, 2000), the sociology of science (actor–network theory; see Latour, 2005), planning (the so-called ‘argumentative’ or ‘deliberative’ turn in planning theory; see Forester, 1989; Healey, 1992; Innes, 1995), and historical sociology of politics and economics (Thompson, 1963; Anderson, 1974; Bayart, 1989/1993; Bayart et al., 1992; Hibou 2006/2011).

It should now be clear that the approach outlined here emphasises understanding and interpretation rather than explanation of social reality in terms of theories and models. It is important to underline that this interdisciplinary, descriptive and case-oriented methodological turn does not entail an abandonment of theoretical ambitions: as Jessop et al. (2008) point out

disp-quote.p: sociospatial theory is most powerful when it (a) refers to historically specific geographies of social relations; and (b) explores contextual and historical variation in the structural coupling, strategic co-ordination, and forms of interconnection among the different dimensions of the latter (Jessop et al., 2008, p. 392).

sec.p: We maintain that theory should develop through a ‘bottom–up’ process in which empirical reality is not a pool of mere samples for the test of pre-existent, theoretically strong hypotheses; with Castells, we could say that urban theory should be “produced and not simply tested by the interpretation of our case studies” (Castells, 1983, p. xviii; see also Ward’s, 2010, concepts of ‘theorizing back’).
At the same time, the recent wave of protests in MENA cities offers us the ideal testing ground for this approach—a descriptive, field-oriented, interpretive methodology.

First, because of its timing and vast geographical spread stretching from Morocco to Syria and beyond, the so-called Arab Spring, invites comparative research—a central element in the theoretical proposal of critical urban studies scholars (Nijman, 2007; McFarlane, 2010; Ward, 2010; Robinson, 2011). We maintain that the numerous and multifaceted protests in different urban contexts in the MENA region offer us unique empirical material to engage in comparative research and theory-building. We do not suggest, of course, a reification of the region through the identification of a supposedly common historical, cultural or social denominator: comparative research should instead offer the opportunity to extend the theoretical reach of urban studies by unsettling the tendency to “compare with and learn from the ‘usual suspects’” (McFarlane, 2010, p. 728; Robinson, 2006). We should recognise that all cities can be legitimate fields for theory-building, and therefore explore the universal relevance of categories and concepts born out of the observation of non-Western urban contexts—how can notions such as ‘non-movements’ (Bayat, 2009) or ‘urban informality’ (Roy, 2005) help us to understand the European or North American reality? This will help us to break the cage of paradigmatic urban theory (Beauregard, 2003) and produce an alternative ‘sociology on a world scale’ (Robinson, 2011; see also McFarlane, 2010).

Secondly, (comparative) research needs to be reframed by dropping the ‘lazy assumptions’ (Robinson, 2011) about the unit of analysis and the reification of the ‘city’ or the ‘state’ as appropriate units of comparison. The dynamic of protest in the MENA region—marked by the relation between urban centres and peripheries, and between different countries—points quite clearly to the roles of cities as multiscalar objects, as intersections of different spatial and political layers (Harders and Legrenzi, 2008). The fact that cities like Cairo and Tunis are more connected to—and visible for—a wider audience, can explain why the spreading of the protest to the main urban centres has been paramount in creating a regional and global momentum and in the emergence of the all-encompassing frame of the ‘Arab Spring’—despite the acknowledged role of small towns and more peripheral contexts as starting-points of the turmoil. Within this perspective, the logistic, media and relational connection between different scales and layers, and the spreading of practices of dissent, represent a legitimate and crucial research object for urban studies.

Last but not least, urban research on MENA cities offers the chance for a healthy process of unsettlement of disciplinary, linguistic and theoretical boundaries. This is far from being a simple rhetorical claim in line with the current methodological fashion. Despite a stated ambition towards this goal, in fact, one would struggle to find non-English references even in the work of scholars such as Jennifer Robinson. This lack of engagement between different academic traditions represents a crucial issue with respect to our field of investigation. MENA cities have been progressively marginalised from the established body of Anglophone urban studies literature. At the same time, the presence of linguistic boundaries—Maghreb countries are Francophone while most of the Middle East, including Egypt, is more influenced by the Anglophone academic tradition—has contributed to the further fragmentation of the academic environment. While this state of the art is in many respects unfortunate, it also offers us a chance to take advantage from the variety in terms of theoretical frames and methodological approaches that resulted from this pattern of parallel development; from the point of view of Anglophone academia in particular, Francophone tradition of research on urban issues can offer a vast array of case study analysis and contributions in the fields of political science and political sociology that have remained so far outside the more commonly accepted frame of urban studies. A more cosmopolitan outlook informed by a descriptive, field-oriented, interpretive approach to urban issues would be the ideal platform to bring these contributions together.

The underlying argument of this Commentary is that the recent debate in urban studies has laid the preliminary conditions for a significant leap forward as far as our understanding of urban theory is concerned. Indeed, this discussion should continue in order to address the main theoretical and methodological issues at the centre of the broader debate on the role of social sciences. At the same time, we maintain that the development of empirical research along these lines—as well as the fostering of continuous exchanges among urban researchers in the form of workshops, conferences and other academic exchanges—should be a fundamental component of this process. We see research on dissent in MENA cities as a meaningful occasion to do so—to adopt a more interpretive approach to social phenomena, embrace comparative urbanism and connect different academic traditions to create an innovative research agenda and produce empirical and theoretical advances.

ack.p: This Critical Commentary develops the ideas behind the workshop proposal “Rethinking cities and social movements in Middle East and North Africa”, submitted by the authors (and by the late Dr Guido Martinotti) to the 2011 Urban Studies Foundation and Urban Studies Journal Seminar Series Competition. Marco Allegra, Irene Bono and Jonathan Rokem developed the Commentary in its present form and are indicated as leading authors; the contribution by Anna Casaglia, Roberta Marzorati and Haim Yacobi to the Commentary is acknowledged because of their role in drafting the original proposal and the continuous feedback provided during the writing process. The authors would also like to thank the editors and the three anonymous referees for their comments on an earlier version of the Commentary.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial or not-for-profit sectors.
